contentrichtext.text: {{coord|25.2|S|271.4|W|type:landmark_globe:europa|display=title|notes=<ref>{{gpn|65047|Pwyll}}</ref>}} [[Image:Europa Pwyll.jpg|right|thumb|350px|A combination of color and high resolution black and white data from [[NASA]]'s [[Galileo probe|Galileo spacecraft]] was used to produce this view looking down on the crater with the sun illuminating the scene from the right. The [[Conamara Chaos]] region is just below the "X" formed by lineae near the top.]] The [[impact crater]] '''Pwyll''' (named after the [[Pwyll]] of [[Welsh mythology]]) is thought to represent one of the youngest features on the surface of [[Jupiter]]'s [[natural satellite|moon]] [[Europa (moon)|Europa]]. Pwyll's visible dark central region is about 26 kilometers in diameter, with a central peak rising to about 600 meters.<ref>{{cite web|title=Red-Blue Three dimensional view of Pwyll crater|url=http://www.jpl.nasa.gov/spaceimages/details.php?id=PIA01665|publisher=Jet Propulsion Laboratory|accessdate=15 December 2012|date=1999-01-18}}</ref> <blockquote>Brilliant rays of debris blasted from the impact site extend outward for hundreds of kilometers. The white debris or ejecta clearly overlays everything else on the surface - indicating that this impact crater is younger than all surrounding features. The bright white color suggests a composition of water ice particles.<ref name=NASAapod41797>{{cite web|title=Astronomy Picture of the Day, April 17, 1997|url=http://apod.nasa.gov/apod/ap970417.html|publisher=NASA|accessdate=15 December 2012}}</ref></blockquote> The instruments of NASA's [[Galileo (spacecraft)|Galileo probe]] uncovered substantial evidence that water in liquid form exists below Europa's icy surface. If Europa has a subsurface ocean, it might also contain life.<ref name=Darling-Europa>{{cite web|last=Darling|first=David|title=Encyclopedia of Science|url=http://www.daviddarling.info/encyclopedia/E/Europa.html|accessdate=15 December 2012}}</ref> NASA is considering ways to investigate the habitability of Europa.<ref name=MWall>{{cite web|last=Wall|first=Mike|title=NASA Eyes Mission to Jupiter Moon Europa|url=http://www.space.com/18901-nasa-mission-jupiter-moon-europa.html|publisher=Space.com|accessdate=15 December 2012|date=13 December 2012}}</ref> The proposed 2020 [[EJSM/Laplace]] mission is unlikely for budgetary reasons. ESA's planned 2022 launch of [[Jupiter Icy Moon Explorer]] would take up that challenge. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == *[http://photojournal.jpl.nasa.gov/catalog/PIA01211 Planetary Photojournal image page] *[http://photojournal.jpl.nasa.gov/feature/+Pwyll+ NASA Europa images] {{DEFAULTSORT:Pwyll (Crater)}} [[Category:Impact craters on Jupiter's moons]] [[Category:Europa (moon)]]
